I love your work John, but I don't recognise the Europe of the past three videos. Obviously we're looking at the big picture and social movements, but the image taken away from the recent videos is of a very dark and unhappy continent. We've been through tough times and many have suffered considerably, but I doubt any of them would have wanted to be anywhere else on earth during these global shocks, protected as they were by European social services. Many turned to populism and hate in the light of the great recession, but the vast majority did not. The efforts of Russia and others to subvert our democracies have failed far more than they've succeeded, and have actually brought many of us together in opposition to us. I'm not trying to minimise the problems we face, but as we head into another recession due to the COVID crisis, we have seen a massive EU recovery programme with huge public support. The EU has survived Brexit, the great recession and the rise of populism and looks well suited to outlast them all. If anything, the rise of these phenomena have reminded Europeans that the status quo is really not so bad, and that reform is needed, not revolution. Meanwhile, hundreds of millions of some of the healthiest, longest lived and most privileged people in human history continue to get educations, enjoy a much better work life balance, health outcome and yes even better politics than the US, for the most part.

Love everything you do, but don't be too down on Europe!

I like your videos but I feel like you do not really understand why populist parties are so populair.
People do not turn to populists parties because they blame the economic crisis on the refugees but because they see the state "waste" money on the refugees that could be invested into ones own struggling population.

The cultural change that many see as unwanted because of the influx of refugees is a second point all together. People who dislike these changes may have been willing in good times to accept the refugees as long as the system causes wealth but the moment letting refugees in causes unwanted chances without the benefits the turn to populism.

Normal citizens don't really care about the European Union, mainly because it ain't really a Union, as it is the U.S or U.K, the European one is mainly a economical and somewhat political union, I mean yeah you feel European, the same way a Tanzanian feels African or a Mongolian... Asian, many European countries aren't part of the E.U yet obviously they feel European people from Switzerland, Norway, Ukraine, Serbia, Russia, Turkey are European but not part of the E.U...

So to answer the question, Country first (although some, many actually, due to the history of the continent feel like they belong to a different country i.e hungarians born in territories that are no longer part of Hungary, Russians from former URSS states that gained independence, Serbians in ex Yugoslavia countries, also we have countries that literally are made from different nationalities, that even if they have a own identify and form a different country, the people in them have different nationalities, Switzerland is made up from French, Italian, and Germans, Belgium from French, Dutch and German, Moldova has Romanians, Ukrainians and Russians, Austria is obviously pretty German (but I won't even dare, get into that)...so:
Country first, Nationality (that may be a different one from that of the country) ethnic or regional group third (I'm referring to the big ones, Slavs, Mediterranean, Northern European, Baltic S.Slavs, Latin etc) , race and religion ain't really as a important as it is in the U.S mainly because as I pointed out, there's quite a few other categories more important for Europeans so for let's say someone is born in Bulgaria, that individual will think about himself as a :
Bulgarian > Slav > European > White > Christian > hentai expert , I used the > to simbolize the order of importance,for this particular individuals identity.

I'm a huge fan of Crash Course and they're work is regularly well researched and well balanced, whilst staying truthful. However I was very dismayed to see they're section on Brexit was hugely off the mark here. The only accurate element was that the vote was not split on party lines. To say that Brexit was an anti-refugee vote, with a side element of paying too much, is a massive oversimplification at best and just plain wrong at worst. Of course, with all political elements, the reasons for Brexit are deep and complex (and I am sure will be debated for the rest of time). And whilst I agree that free movement was one key element (though not the only, for example the cost of membership and the 'undemocratic' nature of the EU were very prominent), I would not agree that anti free movement is the same as anti-refugee (although there are similarities). And I would be very cautious of stating rather boldly it was the main cause of Brexit. For the record, I was and still am an ardent remainer and have a Master's in Political Parties and Elections.

I appreciate that Crash Course covers ALOT of material in a short time, and can not cover everything in the full detail it deserves, but I am disappointed to see how off the mark it was here.

Leftism convinced people that they shouldn't have children because children must be killed in the womb--leading the depopulation and nigh extinction of Europe. Westerners who are the most in favour of low-skilled mass immigration are usually the ones who are the most 'educated' and least affected by its impacts. The definition of Populism used in the video is from post world war 2 era to describe the Populist Movement, a economic movement of Americans in the 1880’s and 1890’s led by William Jennings Bryan. The writers of the new definition described Bryan’s movement of advocating for a 8 hour workday and a progressive income tax system as a proto-fascist movement. Corporatists and big business’s use this false definition of populism to propagate against any attempts at economic reform. During the 1890’s by the “captains of industry’s”. During the 1930’s, 40’s and 50’s to denounce FDR and his New Deal. And now this false form of rhetoric is used by the Corporatist’s in both the Democratic and Republican Party.

I respect John Green a lot, and agree with 99% of Crash Course, but honestly I am not sure that his take on the roots of white nationalism is correct.

Another uncomfortable fact of modern European history, that he does not report, is the demographic decline of European birth rates, simultaneous to the one-way transfer of population from others cultures, with much higher birth rates. Cultures which often have long standing prejudicial, arguably racist, disrespect for European culture. Europe has been a colony of Asian and African empires in the past, it's not invincible, and is not immune to slow cultural conquest, the eventual re-writing of it's history, and the erasure of it's past.

As the child of an immigrant, I can still totally understand why Europe would want to secure itself against open displays of colonialism by some immigrants, such as the open promotion of extremist religion. This unfortunately also gets conflated with anti-Jewish conspiracies and crass unscientific fixations on skin colour by some far right extremists. But I think the two issues are separate, and are unfortunately rarely addressed separately. That there might be a good case for cultural conservation, separate from racism.

Exactly why should Europeans accept immigrants bearing hostile ideologies, ideas and cultural beliefs, who bear a system with an open disregard for their civil rights? You make it sound like it's obviously right, but really no culture has any obligation to house another if the other makes no secret of it's contempt. If immigrants refuse to respect their fellow citizens or the institutions that are housing and educating them, why should they be uncritically accepted, to the potential damage of those very institutions?

In game theory, if one player chooses to play dirty, the others are forced to reciprocate, collapsing agreed mutuality. I think you would find most British voters had no problem with most immigrants. Just the cultural attitudes that led to the frankly horrific gang violence against British women in Rotherham, Rochdale, Oxford, etc, or the terrorist attacks that killed hundreds, not over any noble cause of freedom, but simply because the victims were religious untermensch. Other civilizations like India, China and Japan are equally at risk, and arguably share a common cause with the west. Some immigrants genuinely want to assimilate, so I hope the far right does not transform this into a race issue, and lock out all those who genuinely wish to participate in the grand enterprise of scientific and philosophical truth that started with Plato and Aristotle. Sadly I fear Huntington was right; the wars of the 21st century will be a Clash of Civilizations, as ancient rival ethical systems find they cannot abide each other's most fundamental assumptions on dignity, human freedoms, the nature of reality, the search for truth, or the place of the individual. If that is how it will be, I make no apologies for which ones I want to see win.

That said, I think you overestimate the role of race in European xenophobia. Don't get me wrong, racism is very much a thing here, made especially appearant since the refugee crisis in 2015. But xenophobia against fellow Europeans has been a thing since forever. As long as I remember there was the stereotype of everyone South of Switzerland and East of Thuringia being lazy and Northern European countries' economic successes were attributed to their inhabitants' inherent ability and willingness to work harder, more and more thorough (ignoring how much we owe to post-war immigrants especially from Turkey, Italy and USSR countries).
The effects of the financial crisis on the European Union were, for example, largely blamed on the populations of Greece and Italy.

"Britain received more from the EU than it paid in dues"
That's absolutely false, Britain consistently has been a net contributor to the EU throughout its participation in it, and its predecessor forms, with strings attached, no less. Regularly their contributions were to the tune of 2-3x more than it got back. A good deal for the EU, not so good a deal for the UK. And that's not even including special programmes which they got little out of. And then you have the collapse of their fishing industry. And the working class found themselves permanently pinned to stagflationary minimum wages while house prices ran away from their grasp & mortgage repayment terms grew longer in general. You paint the EU as a one-sided omni-good with no attention to any of the damage it's done at all.

It's been troubling watching what's been going on with the UK. I'm an American based in San Francisco, but part of my ancestry is from the UK, mostly from Fife, Angus, and Nottingham. One of my great great uncles was the founder of Boots UK, and my great great grandfather was the British Consul to Tahiti. I finally got to visit the UK a couple of years ago, and loved how cosmopolitan London's population was. Everyone was perfectly nice, and York, Edinburgh, The Highlands, Liverpool, etc. were lovely. But I don't know how well I'd be received now in the Brexit era; I'm part Filipino, non-binary, and have olive skin. I'm used to being perceived as a foreigner and outsider, but it seems to be more dangerous now.

6:56 was anyone expecting John to say that 😂

White nationalism is not the same as nationalism.

You are simplistic to use the two terms interchangeably.

A nationalist is at heart a person who expects his elected leaders to make every decision based on what is best for the citizens/ voters of that nation, and to put the interest of those citizens first.

In other words, they require their government to be their advocate, without any conflict of interest, and at have a clear commitment to make decisions (within the framework of existing nation states) that will improve their quality of life. Food security. Affordable housing. Jobs. Protection of the natural environment by setting population targets.

To say "nationalism is bad because of Serbia and Nazi Germany" is as ridiculous as saying "a national health system and a public transport system are bad because govt control is socialist and look at Pol Pot and Stalin".

There is a third way. Globalism is not a solution.
